Information vas received in London on the evening of November A. through the French papers, in which

 it said that Ibrahm hosted the white fag[see No. W of the official despatches before sunset the time prescribed by the Admras and if he did 1t would appear that he inclined submit at least for the moment. This news, if true, is likewise important though it is not impossible it is nevertheless very doubtful. The most authentic uH-ofhcial accounts, state that Ibrahm not at Navarn at the time of the battle having been engaged for fortnight in the interior of the Morea, pursuing the Christians Tn the mountains of Messenla, attending the execution of some priests, whom he had crucIfied on some olive trees, making hoocauss of poor peasantry, pack ages of young girls and infants, send into Egypt, and laying the country waste by fire and sword root

 ing up the olives, vines, 6g-trees, &c. &c.

 The Editor of the Morning Herald apprehends that his conduct would be regulated by the of his store. If his provisions short it would be that he could have other alternative than pend hostilties precpate the total destruction of his troops by famine. II, however, statement in the French papers, protesting to be founded on letters from Zante, dated Oct. 25th may be relied on, the hoistng of the white flag by the Egyptian command CT is out of question. According to this sateme mt, Ibrahim Pacha, on being informed of the memora- be events of the Both, had retreated to Coron and had caused all the Greek prisoners, men, women, & children, who had been in his power for the last l5 months, to be put to death by the sword According to the priests aud other persons devoted to !igion, were crucfed, or burnt by slow fire. The de aIis given on ths subject make one shudder but every thing that the last hour of the Egyp tan tyger approaches. The English, French and R ssian flags, have been flying the walls of Maya rlno since the 24th. ModeD must now be in the pow CT of the Triple Alliance The Herald adds, how ever, that the above intelligence appears to of a doubtful character. If it be true it is quite clear l.

 brahm, determined not to surrender, and we do not see how the sangunary monster can be drven out of the Morea, without troops are employed against him. Indeed, it is said that troops will be mlnedi- atey forwarded the iIorea from Gibraltar and the British possessions in the Mediterranean. Private letters from Paris also state that the minister of ma rne had issued orders for the fitting out of several l ships of the line for the Mediterranean"

 But the good news does not stop here. Mir. Ey- nard, the Chairman of the Greek Committee of Swift zerand, writes from Beaulieu Nov. 8, that he has re- ceived official confirmation ofthe account of the Greek fleet having burnt in the Gulf of Iepanto six Turkish brigs, and taken three Austrian transports.

 The Morning Herald of Nov. l5, announces the ar- rival of Mir. Lindsay, with despaches from Vienna, and of lord Ingesrie from Navarino Mir. l.. left Vi- enna on the 9th November The news of the battle of Navarino had reached that city the day before. Previous to Mir. Linsey's departure, the British Am bassador had an interview with Prince Metternch : the result of which interview Mir. l.. has of brought with him. It is understood that the Austrian Cabinet approves--or rather does not complan--o! the destruction of the Austrian transports engaged in the service of the Pacha of Egypt. With respect 10 ,he adyices which Mir. Lindsay brings r. lave the Porte, it is understood that more pacific disposition 1 has begun manifest itself in the Dvan. Al the date, however, of the advices, it should be remem-

 bered that the Porte ignorant of the destruction of the Egyptian fleet. What effect this event will

 have on the councils of the Sutan and apon the pas

 sions of the Turks remain to be seen.

 The Constitutionnel says "the destruction of the fleet by the Allied powers must be serious that the

 shrewdest and penetrating mind cannot calculate ] on it's consequences. There can be no temerlty in

 anticipating real against Turkey, and the de-

 structon of that barbarous empre which has been so

 ong wished for by the sincere and enghned friends l of humanity, who wish for the independence and \ dignity If iu1i IduaIs and natons.p H'Ihe news

 says the paper another place must fall like

 thunderbolt upon the Dyan-and particularly upon ! the Grand Segnor; and have we no reason to teaI

 that in the first of his fury, he may not sci

 bounds to his vengeance aud cruelty Precautions il ! is said are taken in favor of those Europeans who

 are Tn the capital of the Ottoman empire; but what

 precautions can resist the wrath of despot by whose

 nod thousands of heads leap frO the'r shoulders Or
From the ~. Y. Spectator.

NHE subscriber would inform the resi- A- dents and non-residents liable to pay State and Town Tax in the town of Bark hampsted, on the List of 1926, and those in arrears on the Lists 1924 and 1925, that he will meet them to receive said Taxes at the house of Lester Loomen, Esq. Also, all persons liable to pay'a Society tax, to the 1st Ecclesiastical Society in said Barkhamp- sted, on the List 1925, that he will receive their society tax on the day aforementioned at George Merrill's, Those who neglect pay ment must expect to pay fees.

NOTICE.

Palty" and tha; the definition of the word Republi- can is very different from the they had learnt from their fathers of revolutionary memory,-ihat instead off saying, Ia friend government without archy ;-One who wishes place the government m the hands of the people," it says " member of ous party-a supporter of our measures; ;-that the tern federalist-instcad of signifying tone who desires that the independent gHtes of this country may be eagued together for their natural and general good

 that each state shall have the right of governing it's own internal affairs, while it shall submit those reg ulatons which delegation of all the states shall judge best for the interests of the whole ;"-accOrding to the nomenclature in question, is supposed to be an " enemy to Party" which by most natural con- clusion signifies 'an enemy his country "a friend to other" The work has also been found to be strangely inconsistent since it gives long list oi names and has also the magic power ofmaking inser- tions and erasures at pleasure. To each of these names is attached in large characerSthe words, 'Our Party" or '' Our enemy" Scarcely a name, howev- CT, can be found, of those most in vogue, which has not from two to four, and six or eight sures and interlineaons; and that too without the least change in the political character of the indivdu- Out CdpTlCe or the tlneS. noSe erasures, although intended to be complete obera- tions, can be traced out with common magnier and will always be found to be the same alternate words, " Our Party" |" Our Enemy" Now whether the of the Hon. Moves Barber has ever been treated in this manner,we have the means at hand of knowing for as we before remarked, we do no, keep the work Tn question upon our desk, although often reviled for not doing, We shall however re- quire better authority than the editor of the Register that has not been. since what he asserts IS but bare repetition of the discarded authority.

 Our readers we trust will excuse us for thus wan dering fromthe subject in question: fou at Moves Barber, Esq" We never supposed this gentleman to possess any thing than common abities-his re- pub!icanism never doubted, and his being a gen. tieman we never questioned. We however consider ed his vote for Mir. Stevenson an outrage upon the strong evidence that there is "dough' somewhere, whether in his face, in his head, do not say.- He well knew, several months since, that the decree had gone forth from Richmond that Jackson anti tariff man nuSt be Speaker-tha several of the mos; important committees ofhe House must be of the Vir- ginia anti-tarif stamp; and he we'll knew that the freemen of Connecticut were not such dish of skim. med milk wish that of their delegates should lend his aid in bringing about these measures,--and that if he stands on an eminence too high present for just application ofthe word down." he will moi stand many years, unless indeed he is exalted to the Senate reward for his treachery.

 is tut fair remark that the editor ofthe Regis.

 ter guesses that Mr. Barber did not vote for Mir. Ste venson. We, however, guess he did f; and We must

 therefore both wait for higher authority decide the question: By the way, was it it not Mir. Barber who told friend Wells months since that the story of Mir. Adams and Mir. Websters bargaining was true! We only ask for information.

las he the power to stop the arm of hts slaves Ifh had he would have yielded Co the Powers, whom he knows he withstand and that he has not done so IS because he dreaded the fate of his predecessors who had tried m vain to tame the fanaiacism of the Turks. Heaven grant that the Europeans of PeFa may escape the massacre, for which this will be

 he signal r'

 All the French papers appear highly pleased with

 the event. and in exiaces at the part bourne in t by

 heir own ships. Some of the English journals aI- ready show their jealousy of Russia-thinkng that France will obtain Egypt and Russia the European, and part of the Asiatc possessions Of the P0rte and then march upon India at their leisure. letter from Zante says :-"I could attempt to descrie the joy of IOnions the bells tolng, wine is uncori- ed, garlands of flowers suspended from the church doors and every thing indicates the greatest rejoicing at the safety of Greece"

 A letter from Paris of Nov. g. states that the news of this terrible had the effect to lower the funds, and they would have fallen to much great CT extent, had not extraordinary efforts been made by the Minister and his partisans to keep them up The opinions among the merchants with respect to this vent are, of course various but many of the great capitalists entertain considerable apprelensons lest these cou1S de should ultimately lead to some misunderstanding among those who are now singing victory. Some think that Ibrahim, driven to dis par, will listen to proposals made to him by the admirals Destroy vou please the few vessels in the port of Navarn will carry lire and sword thro' the whole of Greecer This threat it is much feared he will be able to carry into effects he has powerful army at his disposal, and the Allies incapable of afOrdng any !mmedate assistance to the unfortunate Greeks, unless, indeed the Russian army crosses the Pruh; and should this event take place, England & France will not view the circnnstance with any de- gree of satisfaction. Austria has always been averse 10 the interference, and will be pleased at the re- suit of the naval fight Every seems 10 anticipate dreadful consequences from what had occurred A possible misunderstanding between the powers-the total exterminaton of the Greek population, and a 1 massacre of the Frank inhabitants residing in the Turkish dominions.'

 NaVarin.-The harbor of Navarn lies at the south corner of the Morea. It is of a roundsh form with island across the mouth of it. The entrance is by the south end of the island where the passage IS 600 yards wde the north entrance is to shallow for large vessels, The island IS two miles long and quarter of mile broad. The bason is six miles in circumference. The port of Navarn is the ancien, harbor of Pyus. In the seventh year of the Peopon. nesian war, Demosthenes the Athenean general sci zed and fortified Pylus. Spartan army immediate ly invaded him there and part of them passed over to the island, than called Sphacera for the purpose of completely blockadng him. while the fleet watch. ed the entrances of the harbor. An Athenan fleet. at last entered the harbor by both mouths atacked the Spartan fleet lying within, and destroyed the whole of it.-The Spartans the island. being cut off from all assstance surrendered prisoners at dis erection to the Ahenians-The late battle was fought on the anniversary of the great battle of Salamis, wherein the Greeks defeated the Persian fleet, on the 20th of October, 480. B. c. 2306 years ago. May indulge the hope that this battle is an omen of an equally happy and glorious deverence for Greece!

Friday, Dec. IA. In the Senate, yesterday, MT. Johnson, ol Ky submitted Resolution for the examin- 1 alton of site on Licking River, Ky. for the establishment of National Armory. similar to that at Harper's Ferry. Mir Dickerson gave notice that he should tomorrow intro duce bill for the distribution of share ofthe Revenue of the U States among the seve- ral States. A resolution was submitted by Mr. Rugges, for the establishment of certain Rules in relation to the mode of doing busi- ness in the Senate. The bin for the abolition of imprisonment for debt was reported from the Committee on that subject, with amend ments, and made the order of the day for Wednesday next.

 In the House of Representatives, number of petitions were presented, and resolutions offered. Among the latter, was resolution offered by Mir. Brent. to institute an inquiry into the public lots in this city. A resolution was offered by Mr P. P. Barbour, referring inquire into the expediency of throwing into the market the stock of seven millions of dol lars held by the Government in the U. States Bank. MT. Barbour explained that his chief object was to obtain the premium at which the stock now stands. and apply it towards the extinguishment of public debt. It was replied by MT. M'Dufie and Mir. Gorhan,, that the very rumor of the intention of Gov ernment to throw that amount of stock into the market, and to withdraw from it's con nection with the Bank, would reduce the stock to its par value. The resolution, on a motion of Mr. Gorhanl, was lad on the ta- ble.

 Saturday, Dec. 15.

 In the Senate yesterday Mr. Harrison submitted a resolution providing for the better accommodation of the Reporters of the Senate. Some discussion on lhe propriety ot receiving the petition Richard Hall, British subject; the objections to receiving it grounded upon the provision of the Constitution, which the right petition citizens of the United States, alone; the petition laid the be. Among other resolutions offered, were two by MT. Smyth, of Md. relative 10 commercial regua- tons; respecting drawbacks and the other for the erection of additional Public Warehouses. short time was spent in Executive business.

 In the House of Representatives, after the presen- taon of petitions, several reports were made from the Standing Committees. Among these, bill was re. ported by Mir. Isacks, from the committee Public Lands to revive and continue force the several acts for the relief of purchasers of public lands. This bill continues the provisions of the former bills to July 1899. 4 bill was introduced by Mir. Wright, relative to the sale of lands conveyed the United States in certain cases which referred to the Committee the Judiciary. X communication from the Treasury Department was laid before the House, enclosing the opinion of the Attorney General in the of Thad- deus Laughlin which was unfavorabe to the petition CT. memorial from Stephen Simpson, ,and J. w. R. Runda of Philadelphia. against the election of Mir. Sergeant, was presented read, and referred to the Committee on Elections. memorial was also pre- sened from Samuel Angus, formerly of the Navy pray ing be reinstated in hls rank and profession Many resolutions offered and adopted, but of them are of great moment.

 Tuesday. Dec. 18, 1927. @ In the Senate, yesterday, Mir. Harrison's resolution, for the better accommodation of the Reporters ofthe proceedings of the Sen- ate was agreed to. Mir Hayne presented the memorial of sundry citizens of Boston and its vicinity, praying that no additional duty be imposed or imports, especially of Woollens which was read and referred. Tine comiHit- tee of Finance reported without amendment. the bill repeating. in parf. the duty on import, ed Salt Mir. Ridgely submitted Resolution referring to Select Committee of five the reyisal and arrangement of the Senate. Mir Johnson of Ky. submitted a Resolution for the examination of all the sites on the West ern Waters. hitherto proposed as suitable foI the establishment of National ArmOry. ir substitution of the Resolution withdrawn by him on Friday. Mir. Webster appeared and took his seat.

 In the House of Representatives, desulto " discussion took place on the subject of the entry on the Journal of Friday, of the pro
From the National Journal.

ceedings on the bill introduced by Mir Wright Of Ohio, relative tO the sale of lands c0nvey- ed to the United States in certain cases. The bill had been introduced with leave of the House, and was read twice and committed to the Committee on the Judiciary. and was so entered on the Journal. This entry was al- legged tO be the entry of a proceeding contra " to the rules of the House. which require that bills thus introduced by the courtesy of the House, should be sent tO a committee to be prepared, before they could be subjected to legislative action. It was moved by Mir. Taylor to amend the Journal but the mo- ton was negatived by vote of IO1 to 68. A subsequent motion was made hy MT. Taylor, to rescind so much of the proceedings of Fri day, as were subsequent to the asking and obtaining leave to introduce the hill referred to, and this motion being successful, that part of the proceedings was resC;nded and the motion of MT. Wright was then referred to the Committee on the Judiciary. with nstruc- tions to prepare and report bill. Several private bills were reported, read and com mItted; and great number of petitions and resolutions were received. A communication was received from the Postmaster Gen"ral.in reply t0 resolution,on the subject ofthe ob- .structions on the Mail Road between Match ez and New Orleans.

 "Wednesday, Dec. 19.

 In :he Senate, yesterday, Mr. Robbins in troduced bill providing for the adjustment Of controversies arising between the State & the United States, which was read and pas scd to second reading. The bill for dstrib- uting among. the several states portion of the revenues of the United States was referred to select committee of seven. Select com mittees were also raised upon the claims of the surviving warriors off the revolution, upon French spolations, and upon the resolution for the revisal and arrangement of the rules of the Senate. The bill authorizing the State OfTenncssee to sell the lands. heretofore ap- propsiated to the use of Schools, was ordered 10 be engrossed for third reading.

 In the House Ofrepresentatiyes, Mir Mitch ell, of Tennessee, offered resolution relative to the removal of the Indians to the West of the Mississsippi,and placing them under ter ritorial government. Several bills were re- ported, and several petitions reported unfav- orably. Among the bills reported was one from the Select Committee on that subject, to authorize the occupation ofthe mouth of the Oregon river. bill was also reported by Mir Strong. allowing the Spanish inhabitants of Florida, who were residents when the ter ritory was transferred to this country, in 1924 the right of voting in any elections of Legis- latlve Council Delegate of Congress, or any other officer. This bill was ordered to be en- crossed, and read third time to-day.

 Thursday. Dec. %.

 In the Senate, yesterday, the bill provid- ing the adjustment of controversies between the States was read second time and refer red to the committee on the Judiciary. The bill for abolishing Imprisonment for debt was taken mp, in Committee the whole, ,and was advocated in a long speech by MT Johnson of Ky.

 In the House of Representatives, bill was reported from the committee on public lands granting relief to purchasers of Public Lands which had reverted in consequence of the non-payment of the purchase money. Some discussion took place on the proposition offer on Tuesday, by MT. Bartlett to amend the 85th Rule of the House so as to preclude the introduction of bill, except by Report of the Committee. After some discussion the bill was laid on the tahe. This discus sion arose out of the erroneous discussion of the Speaker on Friday last. by which bill in troduced by Mr Wright of Ohio, with leave of the House, was suffered to be read twice and committed, without having been first sent to Committee to be prepared, according to the 85th Rule. It will be recollected that on motion of MT. Taylor,the House subsequent ly resclnded the proceeding. Messrs M'Duf- fe and Smith offered joint resolutions con taining propositions for the amendment of the Constitution as relates to the election of Pres ident, which were read, and referred to a Committee ofthe whole on the state of the Union.

 MT SMITH:- We are a trio of youthful poets who have been long seized with the cacOetes scriben dt, and are now burning with ambition to bant

 ngs in print. We have selected your paper for that purpose; and by admitting our communications you will confer favor s and contribute the amuse- ment and the instruction o your readers Our essays will be chiefly poetca; and though they may embrace

 variety of subjects, will ourselves with square two in the poets corner and never trouble you with column. We have made ourselves inti- timately acquainted with the poetica of Horace - we have studied the dead and foreign languages with much attention almost to have forgotten our own; and as are are familiar with the works oi Virgil and Homer, than with those of Murray and Walker, you will please to overlook any triRing gram nautical errors and attribute them the impatience of genius which the vulgar feters of language

 We particularly request that you will attempt penetrate the mystery with which it pleasure to be shrouded for you must be that an incogni- to is always favourable to the saes of wit, and the flights of fancy; and besides, entre nous, we poets fear the lash of cOwhide even than the lash of the critic. Be spariDg too of censure and bear in mind the apophthegm of Johnson, that criticism has

Presidents Message, is the omission press upon the attention of Congress the Tariff question: and urge it to a cordial support ofthe American System" With the utmost proprety this subject left to the discre ton of the Secretary of the Treasury. whose report is principally inserted in paper this day. As sthe dutyof this officer, exclusively, to watch the f. nacial of the country, propose the best constitutional measures for increasing the revenue and to recommend any alteration in the present of income the Treasury, as he is the only Head of Department who is required to make to Congress an annual expose of the of the concerns under his charge, it is really his duty and only his, mend to Congress a revision of the Tariff, whether to increase decrease the present rate of duties. This he has done, in very able and lucId manner and we should suppose the entire satisfaction of even Messrs Wells and Woodward, unless they are like Monsieur Wronghead, who, on entering his house, inquired of his wife, with upon her head, why she had not fed thespgshnd upon being answered hatshe had fed them, he repled-yes I'll it, for you cternaly interfering with that winch does you. First, Mr. Wells comes out with long whining paragraph, complaining that the President is inter- ierng with questions entirely without the constitution al limits by which he should be guarded. In few

 

 bnnkrupsy and ruin, because the President leaves to other constituted authority attention to cer- tain which do not pro perly belong to himself These supposed stretches of power and negects of duty portrayed in lively colors by Mir. Wells, and his heart to swell with all the anxiety of vete- patriot in view the degradation and ruin of his country. Has it, however, heretofore happened that young man, lacking some years of thirty with no more than common knowledge of men and things, has been able to convince an intelligent community that he is better acquainted with all the ramifcations of national government, than old and able n,who filled high offices with hononr themselves and their constituents long before he had being ?- Can he make them believe that when he censures, there is for censurethat his approval of men and measures is proof positive of their excellence will his ceaseless attempts at showing his very superb or knowledge of affairs only tend excite pity for his weakness and disgust for his oficiousness =? As for MT. Woodward, he has not the appear of honesty, eandor, and intelligence, which to superficial reader characterizes his brother Wells ]; but with his accustomed rashness in political matters, he rattles away hap-hazard whatever uppermost in his mind, without expressing desire to throw his bold assertions the mantle of truth and dor. What he says he says with vengeance, and leaves it for loggerheads decide upon the import which is attached to his articles; for even the editor himself is not dolt enough suppose that of sense will be iufuencedby his wild theories.

 {" Lost Chaa.'-Near the close of the day Mon day, l7th inst. William Darling Iritchard, lovely sprighty child, aged years of Mr. Darling Pritchard of Milton Society, left home in search of his father whom he thought to find at the forge. He told by the workmen that his father had gone into the woods, whether the thoughtess wanderer, it aE rewards appeared, turned his steps. All the feelings of parents heart awakened when Mr. P. re- turned to his house, and to the anxious enquiries of the mother for her lovely boy he learnt that his had heedessy strayed away in search of him. Enquiries were made at the forge, and the father could only learn that his child astseen tho bridge. search immediately commenced; but as it conjec- tured that he have fallen into the the neigh bors penetrated but little way into the woods. The mill pond drawn off, and the neighbours commenced raking the waters for the body, which labor continued until Thursday. The search then extended into the woods, where, in a short tme, under cluster of bushes the lfeless and fro- body of the little sufferer was found. It appear cd that on the Monday evening proceeding, some in- dviduals engaged in the search. had gone within a. bout twenty rods of the spot where the child lay but from mistaken notion that he had fallen from the bridge, the undivided attention of the people was turned to searching for the body in the river. The child had gone but little distance into the wood, when he was probably overcome by seer occasioned by chill and crawed under bush, when three days afterwards his body was found.

 The democratic nerves ofour brother of the'' Re- gister appear to have been considerably agitated at the notice, in last, of Hon, Moves Barber and as- that this fout," to his elegant dicton, which we uttered against the hon. member, was be- cause he is gentleman and old school repubIi- can.'' It is passing strange that should suffer such iapsus psnn9 go forth to the world, in the very teeth of our better judgment for have always entertained sentiments of high respect for the charac ter of real gentlemen and feelings bordering upon veneration for well tried, old school republicans We however free to acknowledge that do no make use exclusively of the political lexicon our brother Barber;hs appears to be lettered upon the back, with the word PARTY, while ours is lettered PRINCIPLE. We have had the former urged upon us; but upon examining its contents, and comparing it with the latter, forcby struck with the in- constituencies of the and the excellencies of the ..
@OWNTY l0OsT.
LTTCHFIELD, DECEMBER 9, 1927.

He vas one of the most eDterprisng, useful, and respectable citizens of Portage county His remains brought to Harpersfeld, and inter- coucourse of Brethren and friends attended with his afflicted family to pay the last tribute of respect to de- parted worth.

 In Boston, on the 18th inst. by Rev. Edward Beech CT, Rev. Austin Richards, of Francestown, N. H. to Miss Maria Creighton only daughter of Hon. George Odorne, and granddaughter of Rev. James Creighton of London.

 In Danbury, Mir Alfred Benedict to Clarinda Dke- man.

 Eunce Bronson. Mir Royal Davis to Miss Orinda A. Smith.
AaaR R NE n

full articles.headline: DAVID REA'S ESTATE.
full articles.article:
WYE. the undersigned, having been ap- w pointed by the hon. Court of Probate for the District of Litchfeld, Commissioners to receive, examine, adjust, and settle the claims of the several creditors of the estate of

 DAVID REA,

 late of Litchfed in said district, deceased, represented insolyent Band Ssaid judge having limited and allowed six months from and af- ter the goth day of instant December, for the ere di ors of said estate to exhibit their claims, hereby give notice that wesshall lmeet at the late dwelling house of said sdeceased, on the 21st day of March and of June next, at one o'clock in the afternoon on each of said days, for the purpose of attending to the business of our said appointment. All claims not pre- sented within the time limited aforesaid, prop erly attested, will be forever foreelosed and barred recovery.

 NATHAN GOODWIN, ) couo

 SIMEON SANFORD, o"' :

 RUFUS PICKETT, '''"'''' Litchfeld, Dec. 19,:1S97. 9S

full articles.headline: From the ~. Y. Spectator.
full articles.article:
Information vas received in London on the evening of November A. through the French papers, in which

 it said that Ibrahm hosted the white fag[see No. W of the official despatches before sunset the time prescribed by the Admras and if he did 1t would appear that he inclined submit at least for the moment. This news, if true, is likewise important though it is not impossible it is nevertheless very doubtful. The most authentic uH-ofhcial accounts, state that Ibrahm not at Navarn at the time of the battle having been engaged for fortnight in the interior of the Morea, pursuing the Christians Tn the mountains of Messenla, attending the execution of some priests, whom he had crucIfied on some olive trees, making hoocauss of poor peasantry, pack ages of young girls and infants, send into Egypt, and laying the country waste by fire and sword root

 ing up the olives, vines, 6g-trees, &c. &c.

 The Editor of the Morning Herald apprehends that his conduct would be regulated by the of his store. If his provisions short it would be that he could have other alternative than pend hostilties precpate the total destruction of his troops by famine. II, however, statement in the French papers, protesting to be founded on letters from Zante, dated Oct. 25th may be relied on, the hoistng of the white flag by the Egyptian command CT is out of question. According to this sateme mt, Ibrahim Pacha, on being informed of the memora- be events of the Both, had retreated to Coron and had caused all the Greek prisoners, men, women, & children, who had been in his power for the last l5 months, to be put to death by the sword According to the priests aud other persons devoted to !igion, were crucfed, or burnt by slow fire. The de aIis given on ths subject make one shudder but every thing that the last hour of the Egyp tan tyger approaches. The English, French and R ssian flags, have been flying the walls of Maya rlno since the 24th. ModeD must now be in the pow CT of the Triple Alliance The Herald adds, how ever, that the above intelligence appears to of a doubtful character. If it be true it is quite clear l.

 brahm, determined not to surrender, and we do not see how the sangunary monster can be drven out of the Morea, without troops are employed against him. Indeed, it is said that troops will be mlnedi- atey forwarded the iIorea from Gibraltar and the British possessions in the Mediterranean. Private letters from Paris also state that the minister of ma rne had issued orders for the fitting out of several l ships of the line for the Mediterranean"

 But the good news does not stop here. Mir. Ey- nard, the Chairman of the Greek Committee of Swift zerand, writes from Beaulieu Nov. 8, that he has re- ceived official confirmation ofthe account of the Greek fleet having burnt in the Gulf of Iepanto six Turkish brigs, and taken three Austrian transports.

 The Morning Herald of Nov. l5, announces the ar- rival of Mir. Lindsay, with despaches from Vienna, and of lord Ingesrie from Navarino Mir. l.. left Vi- enna on the 9th November The news of the battle of Navarino had reached that city the day before. Previous to Mir. Linsey's departure, the British Am bassador had an interview with Prince Metternch : the result of which interview Mir. l.. has of brought with him. It is understood that the Austrian Cabinet approves--or rather does not complan--o! the destruction of the Austrian transports engaged in the service of the Pacha of Egypt. With respect 10 ,he adyices which Mir. Lindsay brings r. lave the Porte, it is understood that more pacific disposition 1 has begun manifest itself in the Dvan. Al the date, however, of the advices, it should be remem-

 bered that the Porte ignorant of the destruction of the Egyptian fleet. What effect this event will

 have on the councils of the Sutan and apon the pas

 sions of the Turks remain to be seen.

 The Constitutionnel says "the destruction of the fleet by the Allied powers must be serious that the

 shrewdest and penetrating mind cannot calculate ] on it's consequences. There can be no temerlty in

 anticipating real against Turkey, and the de-

 structon of that barbarous empre which has been so

 ong wished for by the sincere and enghned friends l of humanity, who wish for the independence and \ dignity If iu1i IduaIs and natons.p H'Ihe news

 says the paper another place must fall like

 thunderbolt upon the Dyan-and particularly upon ! the Grand Segnor; and have we no reason to teaI

 that in the first of his fury, he may not sci

 bounds to his vengeance aud cruelty Precautions il ! is said are taken in favor of those Europeans who

 are Tn the capital of the Ottoman empire; but what

 precautions can resist the wrath of despot by whose

 nod thousands of heads leap frO the'r shoulders Or

full articles.headline: Good Stand for a Shoemaker.
full articles.article:
LNOR SALE. about ten acres Of LAND, N with small and convenient Dwelling house md Barr standings.ihereOn, situate a- bout Sixty ROaS north of the meeting-house, in Be;dlrm. About one and an half acres of the above is covered with Wood, and the re- mainder is fenced into convenient Moving. Pasture, and PlOw Lots. It is an excellent stand for Tanner and Shoe maker, there being none of that occupation in the 'vicin- ity. The place will be sold cheap, a1d the terms of payment made easy.

 AppIy,t"

 JOSEPHEH.iBELLAMY. Bethlem. Dee. 2G, IGe7. 6w28

full articles.headline:
NOTICE

NOTICE.
full articles.article:
NHE subscriber would inform the resi- A- dents and non-residents liable to pay State and Town Tax in the town of Bark hampsted, on the List of 1926, and those in arrears on the Lists 1924 and 1925, that he will meet them to receive said Taxes at the house of Lester Loomen, Esq. Jan. %, 1928, at Amasa Malory's, 23d. Jesse Ives, 24th, & George Merrill, a5th of said Jan. from 12 till o'clock, PM. on each of said days. Also, all persons liable to pay'a Society tax, to the 1st Ecclesiastical Society in said Barkhamp- sted, on the List 1925, that he will receive their society tax on the day aforementioned at George Merrill's, Those who neglect pay ment must expect to pay fees.

 ORVILL HOWET, Collector.

 Barkhampsted, Dec. Is, 1897. 9a

Palty" and tha; the definition of the word Republi- can is very different from the they had learnt from their fathers of revolutionary memory,-ihat instead off saying, Ia friend government without archy ;-One who wishes place the government m the hands of the people," it says " member of ous party-a supporter of our measures; ;-that the tern federalist-instcad of signifying tone who desires that the independent gHtes of this country may be eagued together for their natural and general good

 that each state shall have the right of governing it's own internal affairs, while it shall submit those reg ulatons which delegation of all the states shall judge best for the interests of the whole ;"-accOrding to the nomenclature in question, is supposed to be an " enemy to Party" which by most natural con- clusion signifies 'an enemy his country "a friend to other" The work has also been found to be strangely inconsistent since it gives long list oi names and has also the magic power ofmaking inser- tions and erasures at pleasure. To each of these names is attached in large characerSthe words, 'Our Party" or '' Our enemy" Scarcely a name, howev- CT, can be found, of those most in vogue, which has not from two to four, and six or eight sures and interlineaons; and that too without the least change in the political character of the indivdu- Out CdpTlCe or the tlneS. noSe erasures, although intended to be complete obera- tions, can be traced out with common magnier and will always be found to be the same alternate words, " Our Party" |" Our Enemy" Now whether the of the Hon. Moves Barber has ever been treated in this manner,we have the means at hand of knowing for as we before remarked, we do no, keep the work Tn question upon our desk, although often reviled for not doing, We shall however re- quire better authority than the editor of the Register that has not been. since what he asserts IS but bare repetition of the discarded authority.

 Our readers we trust will excuse us for thus wan dering fromthe subject in question: fou at Moves Barber, Esq" We never supposed this gentleman to possess any thing than common abities-his re- pub!icanism never doubted, and his being a gen. tieman we never questioned. We however consider ed his vote for Mir. Stevenson an outrage upon the strong evidence that there is "dough' somewhere, whether in his face, in his head, do not say.- He well knew, several months since, that the decree had gone forth from Richmond that Jackson anti tariff man nuSt be Speaker-tha several of the mos; important committees ofhe House must be of the Vir- ginia anti-tarif stamp; and he we'll knew that the freemen of Connecticut were not such dish of skim. med milk wish that of their delegates should lend his aid in bringing about these measures,--and that if he stands on an eminence too high present for just application ofthe word down." he will moi stand many years, unless indeed he is exalted to the Senate reward for his treachery.

 is tut fair remark that the editor ofthe Regis.

 ter guesses that Mr. Barber did not vote for Mir. Ste venson. We, however, guess he did f; and We must

 therefore both wait for higher authority decide the question: By the way, was it it not Mir. Barber who told friend Wells months since that the story of Mir. Adams and Mir. Websters bargaining was true! We only ask for information.

 By order of said court,

 MARTIN WEBSTER, Adn. Torrington, Dec. 91,1S27. 9a

full articles.article:

Court of Probate for the dis trct of Ltchffeld. all the personal property texeept the portion assigned by the court to the widowl of the estate ofREUEL COGGSWELI.. late of Wash. ington in said district, deceased, will be sold at pub lie auction on Wednesday the second day ofJanusry 1928, at 10 o'clock A. M at the late dwelling houss of the deceased, in said tOwn unless previously dis posed of at private sale.

 Washington, Dee. IA, 1927. W

las he the power to stop the arm of hts slaves Ifh had he would have yielded Co the Powers, whom he knows he withstand and that he has not done so IS because he dreaded the fate of his predecessors who had tried m vain to tame the fanaiacism of the Turks. Heaven grant that the Europeans of PeFa may escape the massacre, for which this will be

 he signal r'

 All the French papers appear highly pleased with

 the event. and in exiaces at the part bourne in t by

 heir own ships. Some of the English journals aI- ready show their jealousy of Russia-thinkng that France will obtain Egypt and Russia the European, and part of the Asiatc possessions Of the P0rte and then march upon India at their leisure. letter from Zante says :-"I could attempt to descrie the joy of IOnions the bells tolng, wine is uncori- ed, garlands of flowers suspended from the church doors and every thing indicates the greatest rejoicing at the safety of Greece"

 A letter from Paris of Nov. g. states that the news of this terrible had the effect to lower the funds, and they would have fallen to much great CT extent, had not extraordinary efforts been made by the Minister and his partisans to keep them up The opinions among the merchants with respect to this vent are, of course various but many of the great capitalists entertain considerable apprelensons lest these cou1S de should ultimately lead to some misunderstanding among those who are now singing victory. Some think that Ibrahim, driven to dis par, will listen to proposals made to him by the admirals Destroy vou please the few vessels in the port of Navarn will carry lire and sword thro' the whole of Greecer This threat it is much feared he will be able to carry into effects he has powerful army at his disposal, and the Allies incapable of afOrdng any !mmedate assistance to the unfortunate Greeks, unless, indeed the Russian army crosses the Pruh; and should this event take place, England & France will not view the circnnstance with any de- gree of satisfaction. Austria has always been averse 10 the interference, and will be pleased at the re- suit of the naval fight Every seems 10 anticipate dreadful consequences from what had occurred A possible misunderstanding between the powers-the total exterminaton of the Greek population, and a 1 massacre of the Frank inhabitants residing in the Turkish dominions.'

 NaVarin.-The harbor of Navarn lies at the south corner of the Morea. It is of a roundsh form with island across the mouth of it. The entrance is by the south end of the island where the passage IS 600 yards wde the north entrance is to shallow for large vessels, The island IS two miles long and quarter of mile broad. The bason is six miles in circumference. The port of Navarn is the ancien, harbor of Pyus. In the seventh year of the Peopon. nesian war, Demosthenes the Athenean general sci zed and fortified Pylus. Spartan army immediate ly invaded him there and part of them passed over to the island, than called Sphacera for the purpose of completely blockadng him. while the fleet watch. ed the entrances of the harbor. An Athenan fleet. at last entered the harbor by both mouths atacked the Spartan fleet lying within, and destroyed the whole of it.-The Spartans the island. being cut off from all assstance surrendered prisoners at dis erection to the Ahenians-The late battle was fought on the anniversary of the great battle of Salamis, wherein the Greeks defeated the Persian fleet, on the 20th of October, 480. B. c. 2306 years ago. May indulge the hope that this battle is an omen of an equally happy and glorious deverence for Greece!

full articles.headline: From the National Journal.
full articles.article:
Friday, Dec. IA. In the Senate, yesterday, MT. Johnson, ol Ky submitted Resolution for the examin- 1 alton of site on Licking River, Ky. for the establishment of National Armory. similar to that at Harper's Ferry. Mir Dickerson gave notice that he should tomorrow intro duce bill for the distribution of share ofthe Revenue of the U States among the seve- ral States. A resolution was submitted by Mr. Rugges, for the establishment of certain Rules in relation to the mode of doing busi- ness in the Senate. The bin for the abolition of imprisonment for debt was reported from the Committee on that subject, with amend ments, and made the order of the day for Wednesday next.

 In the House of Representatives, number of petitions were presented, and resolutions offered. Among the latter, was resolution offered by Mir. Brent. to institute an inquiry into the public lots in this city. A resolution was offered by Mr P. P. Barbour, referring inquire into the expediency of throwing into the market the stock of seven millions of dol lars held by the Government in the U. States Bank. MT. Barbour explained that his chief object was to obtain the premium at which the stock now stands. and apply it towards the extinguishment of public debt. It was replied by MT. M'Dufie and Mir. Gorhan,, that the very rumor of the intention of Gov ernment to throw that amount of stock into the market, and to withdraw from it's con nection with the Bank, would reduce the stock to its par value. The resolution, on a motion of Mr. Gorhanl, was lad on the ta- ble.

 Saturday, Dec. 15.

 In the Senate yesterday Mr. Harrison submitted a resolution providing for the better accommodation of the Reporters of the Senate. Some discussion on lhe propriety ot receiving the petition Richard Hall, British subject; the objections to receiving it grounded upon the provision of the Constitution, which the right petition citizens of the United States, alone; the petition laid the be. Among other resolutions offered, were two by MT. Smyth, of Md. relative 10 commercial regua- tons; respecting drawbacks and the other for the erection of additional Public Warehouses. short time was spent in Executive business.

 In the House of Representatives, after the presen- taon of petitions, several reports were made from the Standing Committees. Among these, bill was re. ported by Mir. Isacks, from the committee Public Lands to revive and continue force the several acts for the relief of purchasers of public lands. This bill continues the provisions of the former bills to July 1899. 4 bill was introduced by Mir. Wright, relative to the sale of lands conveyed the United States in certain cases which referred to the Committee the Judiciary. X communication from the Treasury Department was laid before the House, enclosing the opinion of the Attorney General in the of Thad- deus Laughlin which was unfavorabe to the petition CT. memorial from Stephen Simpson, ,and J. w. R. Runda of Philadelphia. against the election of Mir. Sergeant, was presented read, and referred to the Committee on Elections. memorial was also pre- sened from Samuel Angus, formerly of the Navy pray ing be reinstated in hls rank and profession Many resolutions offered and adopted, but of them are of great moment.

 Tuesday. Dec. 18, 1927. @ In the Senate, yesterday, Mir. Harrison's resolution, for the better accommodation of the Reporters ofthe proceedings of the Sen- ate was agreed to. Mir Hayne presented the memorial of sundry citizens of Boston and its vicinity, praying that no additional duty be imposed or imports, especially of Woollens which was read and referred. Tine comiHit- tee of Finance reported without amendment. the bill repeating. in parf. the duty on import, ed Salt Mir. Ridgely submitted Resolution referring to Select Committee of five the reyisal and arrangement of the Senate. Mir Johnson of Ky. submitted a Resolution for the examination of all the sites on the West ern Waters. hitherto proposed as suitable foI the establishment of National ArmOry. ir substitution of the Resolution withdrawn by him on Friday. Mir. Webster appeared and took his seat.

 In the House of Representatives, desulto " discussion took place on the subject of the entry on the Journal of Friday, of the pro

ceedings on the bill introduced by Mir Wright Of Ohio, relative tO the sale of lands c0nvey- ed to the United States in certain cases. The bill had been introduced with leave of the House, and was read twice and committed to the Committee on the Judiciary. and was so entered on the Journal. This entry was al- legged tO be the entry of a proceeding contra " to the rules of the House. which require that bills thus introduced by the courtesy of the House, should be sent tO a committee to be prepared, before they could be subjected to legislative action. It was moved by Mir. Taylor to amend the Journal but the mo- ton was negatived by vote of IO1 to 68. A subsequent motion was made hy MT. Taylor, to rescind so much of the proceedings of Fri day, as were subsequent to the asking and obtaining leave to introduce the hill referred to, and this motion being successful, that part of the proceedings was resC;nded and the motion of MT. Wright was then referred to the Committee on the Judiciary. with nstruc- tions to prepare and report bill. Several private bills were reported, read and com mItted; and great number of petitions and resolutions were received. A communication was received from the Postmaster Gen"ral.in reply t0 resolution,on the subject ofthe ob- .structions on the Mail Road between Match ez and New Orleans.

 "Wednesday, Dec. 19.

 In :he Senate, yesterday, Mr. Robbins in troduced bill providing for the adjustment Of controversies arising between the State & the United States, which was read and pas scd to second reading. The bill for dstrib- uting among. the several states portion of the revenues of the United States was referred to select committee of seven. Select com mittees were also raised upon the claims of the surviving warriors off the revolution, upon French spolations, and upon the resolution for the revisal and arrangement of the rules of the Senate. The bill authorizing the State OfTenncssee to sell the lands. heretofore ap- propsiated to the use of Schools, was ordered 10 be engrossed for third reading.

 In the House Ofrepresentatiyes, Mir Mitch ell, of Tennessee, offered resolution relative to the removal of the Indians to the West of the Mississsippi,and placing them under ter ritorial government. Several bills were re- ported, and several petitions reported unfav- orably. Among the bills reported was one from the Select Committee on that subject, to authorize the occupation ofthe mouth of the Oregon river. bill was also reported by Mir Strong. allowing the Spanish inhabitants of Florida, who were residents when the ter ritory was transferred to this country, in 1924 the right of voting in any elections of Legis- latlve Council Delegate of Congress, or any other officer. This bill was ordered to be en- crossed, and read third time to-day.

 Thursday. Dec. %.

 In the Senate, yesterday, the bill provid- ing the adjustment of controversies between the States was read second time and refer red to the committee on the Judiciary. The bill for abolishing Imprisonment for debt was taken mp, in Committee the whole, ,and was advocated in a long speech by MT Johnson of Ky.

 In the House of Representatives, bill was reported from the committee on public lands granting relief to purchasers of Public Lands which had reverted in consequence of the non-payment of the purchase money. Some discussion took place on the proposition offer on Tuesday, by MT. Bartlett to amend the 85th Rule of the House so as to preclude the introduction of bill, except by Report of the Committee. After some discussion the bill was laid on the tahe. This discus sion arose out of the erroneous discussion of the Speaker on Friday last. by which bill in troduced by Mr Wright of Ohio, with leave of the House, was suffered to be read twice and committed, without having been first sent to Committee to be prepared, according to the 85th Rule. It will be recollected that on motion of MT. Taylor,the House subsequent ly resclnded the proceeding. Messrs M'Duf- fe and Smith offered joint resolutions con taining propositions for the amendment of the Constitution as relates to the election of Pres ident, which were read, and referred to a Committee ofthe whole on the state of the Union.

 MT SMITH:- We are a trio of youthful poets who have been long seized with the cacOetes scriben dt, and are now burning with ambition to bant

 ngs in print. We have selected your paper for that purpose; and by admitting our communications you will confer favor s and contribute the amuse- ment and the instruction o your readers Our essays will be chiefly poetca; and though they may embrace

 variety of subjects, will ourselves with square two in the poets corner and never trouble you with column. We have made ourselves inti- timately acquainted with the poetica of Horace - we have studied the dead and foreign languages with much attention almost to have forgotten our own; and as are are familiar with the works oi Virgil and Homer, than with those of Murray and Walker, you will please to overlook any triRing gram nautical errors and attribute them the impatience of genius which the vulgar feters of language

 We particularly request that you will attempt penetrate the mystery with which it pleasure to be shrouded for you must be that an incogni- to is always favourable to the saes of wit, and the flights of fancy; and besides, entre nous, we poets fear the lash of cOwhide even than the lash of the critic. Be spariDg too of censure and bear in mind the apophthegm of Johnson, that criticism has

full articles.headline:
@OWNTY l0OsT.

LTTCHFIELD, DECEMBER 9, 1927.
full articles.article:
Presidents Message, is the omission press upon the attention of Congress the Tariff question: and urge it to a cordial support ofthe American System" With the utmost proprety this subject left to the discre ton of the Secretary of the Treasury. whose report is principally inserted in paper this day. As sthe dutyof this officer, exclusively, to watch the f. nacial of the country, propose the best constitutional measures for increasing the revenue and to recommend any alteration in the present of income the Treasury, as he is the only Head of Department who is required to make to Congress an annual expose of the of the concerns under his charge, it is really his duty and only his, mend to Congress a revision of the Tariff, whether to increase decrease the present rate of duties. This he has done, in very able and lucId manner and we should suppose the entire satisfaction of even Messrs Wells and Woodward, unless they are like Monsieur Wronghead, who, on entering his house, inquired of his wife, with upon her head, why she had not fed thespgshnd upon being answered hatshe had fed them, he repled-yes I'll it, for you cternaly interfering with that winch does you. First, Mr. Wells comes out with long whining paragraph, complaining that the President is inter- ierng with questions entirely without the constitution al limits by which he should be guarded. In few

 

 bnnkrupsy and ruin, because the President leaves to other constituted authority attention to cer- tain which do not pro perly belong to himself These supposed stretches of power and negects of duty portrayed in lively colors by Mir. Wells, and his heart to swell with all the anxiety of vete- patriot in view the degradation and ruin of his country. Has it, however, heretofore happened that young man, lacking some years of thirty with no more than common knowledge of men and things, has been able to convince an intelligent community that he is better acquainted with all the ramifcations of national government, than old and able n,who filled high offices with hononr themselves and their constituents long before he had being ?- Can he make them believe that when he censures, there is for censurethat his approval of men and measures is proof positive of their excellence will his ceaseless attempts at showing his very superb or knowledge of affairs only tend excite pity for his weakness and disgust for his oficiousness =? As for MT. Woodward, he has not the appear of honesty, eandor, and intelligence, which to superficial reader characterizes his brother Wells ]; but with his accustomed rashness in political matters, he rattles away hap-hazard whatever uppermost in his mind, without expressing desire to throw his bold assertions the mantle of truth and dor. What he says he says with vengeance, and leaves it for loggerheads decide upon the import which is attached to his articles; for even the editor himself is not dolt enough suppose that of sense will be iufuencedby his wild theories.

 {" Lost Chaa.'-Near the close of the day Mon day, l7th inst. William Darling Iritchard, lovely sprighty child, aged years of Mr. Darling Pritchard of Milton Society, left home in search of his father whom he thought to find at the forge. He told by the workmen that his father had gone into the woods, whether the thoughtess wanderer, it aE rewards appeared, turned his steps. All the feelings of parents heart awakened when Mr. P. re- turned to his house, and to the anxious enquiries of the mother for her lovely boy he learnt that his had heedessy strayed away in search of him. Enquiries were made at the forge, and the father could only learn that his child astseen tho bridge. search immediately commenced; but as it conjec- tured that he have fallen into the the neigh bors penetrated but little way into the woods. The mill pond drawn off, and the neighbours commenced raking the waters for the body, which labor continued until Thursday. The search then extended into the woods, where, in a short tme, under cluster of bushes the lfeless and fro- body of the little sufferer was found. It appear cd that on the Monday evening proceeding, some in- dviduals engaged in the search. had gone within a. bout twenty rods of the spot where the child lay but from mistaken notion that he had fallen from the bridge, the undivided attention of the people was turned to searching for the body in the river. The child had gone but little distance into the wood, when he was probably overcome by seer occasioned by chill and crawed under bush, when three days afterwards his body was found.

 The democratic nerves ofour brother of the'' Re- gister appear to have been considerably agitated at the notice, in last, of Hon, Moves Barber and as- that this fout," to his elegant dicton, which we uttered against the hon. member, was be- cause he is gentleman and old school repubIi- can.'' It is passing strange that should suffer such iapsus psnn9 go forth to the world, in the very teeth of our better judgment for have always entertained sentiments of high respect for the charac ter of real gentlemen and feelings bordering upon veneration for well tried, old school republicans We however free to acknowledge that do no make use exclusively of the political lexicon our brother Barber;hs appears to be lettered upon the back, with the word PARTY, while ours is lettered PRINCIPLE. We have had the former urged upon us; but upon examining its contents, and comparing it with the latter, forcby struck with the in- constituencies of the and the excellencies of the ..

 GROVE CATLIN. LitchfeId, Dec. %, 1927, s8

MASONIC.

 THE Sir Knights of Clinton Encampment N No. s, are notified that their regular meeting is adjourned to the 2d day of Janua- ry, 1928, to meet at the Hall, at one o'clock, M. A punctial attendance is requested.

 By order of M. E. G. Commander. Washington, Dec. 94, 1927. 28

of Rev. Noah Beuedict formerly of Hartford.

 In Torringford widow Ruth Gaylord, aged 78.

 In Portage County, Ohio, very suddenly on the 18th of September, while absent from home on business, Solomon L. Barney Esq. of Harpersfed, Ashtabua Go. formerly of Wllsborough, N. Y. and native of Canaan, Conn. He vas one of the most eDterprisng, useful, and respectable citizens of Portage county His remains brought to Harpersfeld, and inter- coucourse of Brethren and friends attended with his afflicted family to pay the last tribute of respect to de- parted worth.

 In Hopkinton, N. H. by drowning, Mrs Farwell wife of Dea. Thomas Farwell.

 In New-Prcston, Dec. Duh, Hezekiah Whitney aged 80, . Revolutionary Pensoner.
